case_name: Swarajya Lakshmi v. Dr. G. G. Padma Rao

facts.text: Civil appeal No. 2248 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil appeal No. 2248 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the ju

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 22, 1969 of Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgement and Order dated the 2nd July, 1969, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in appeal against order No. 224 of 1966.

facts.text: High Court appeal against order No. 224 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: ...Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in appeal against order No. 224 of 1966. S. chitle K. Rajendra Choudhury...

facts.text: Respondent Dr. G. G. Padma Rao filed petition against appellant Swarajya Lakshmi under Sec. 13(1)(iv) of Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 for divorce on ground of appellant suffering from virulent and incurable leprosy for not less than three years preceding petition.

anchor.surface_text: ...in companynection with a petition filed by respondent Dr. G. G. Padma Rao against the appellant Swarajya Lakshmi under, Sec. 13 1  iv  of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 for the dissolution of the marriage between them by a decree of divorce on the ground that the appellant had for a period of number less than three years immediately preceding the presentation of the petition been suffering from a virulent and incurable form of leprosy.

facts.text: Appellant and respondent married on June 17, 1963; appellant aged 20, respondent 28.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the respondent were married on June 17, 1963. The appellant was then 20 and the respondent, her husband, was 28 years of age.

facts.text: Appellant taken away by parents to New Delhi two days after marriage; returned to Hyderabad end of August 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, we are told, was taken away by her parents of New Delhi only two, days after the, marriage she returned to Hyderabad to live with her husband only towards the end of August 1963.

facts.text: In September 1963, respondent discovered appellant suffering from leprosy and tuberculosis.

anchor.surface_text: Almost immediately thereafter in the month of September her husband discovered that she was suffering both from Leporsy and Tuberculosis.

facts.text: Respondent, a doctor, treated appellant and consulted Dr. C. V. Ethirajulu and Dr. Shanti Narayan Mathur.

anchor.surface_text: He being a doctor started treating the wife immediately. Not companytent with his own treatment he companysulted also two experts namely Dr. C. V. Ethirajuju and Dr. Shanti Narayan Mathur.

facts.text: Appellant taken by father to New Delhi in May 1964 as expecting child; respondent had contemplated admitting her to leper home.

anchor.surface_text: At one point of time the respondent seriously companytemplated admitting the appellant to a leper home, but the appellant was taken away by her father to New Delhi in May 1964 as she was then expecting a child,

facts.text: Respondent filed petition for dissolution of marriage on June 4, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On June 4, 1965 the respondent filed a petition under the Hindu Marriage Act  hereinafter referred to as the said Act  for, dissolution of his marriage with the appellant.

facts.text: City Civil Court Hyderabad granted permission under Sec. 14(1) to present petition before three years from marriage due to exceptional hardship.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of Presenting this petition he made an application under Sec. 14 1  of the said Act before the City Civil Court at Hyderabad for permisSion to present the petition before three years had elapsed from the date of the marriage on the ground that the case was one of exceptional hardship to the respondent. The permission was granted...

facts.text: Second Additional Chief Judge, City Civil Court, Hyderabad on February 22, 1966 held appellant suffered from virulent incurable leprosy for not less than three years preceding petition but petition premature as parties not husband-wife for three years; dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: On February 22, 1966 the, Second Additional. Chief Judge, City Civil Court, Hyderabad who heard the Petition passed an order by which he held  a  that Swarajya Lakshmi, the appellant, had been suffering from an incurable and virulent form of leprosy for a period number less than three years immediately preceding the presentation of the petition but  b  that the petition was, premature...

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Andhra Pradesh High Court; Division Bench allowed appeal on July 22, 1969, set aside lower court order, granted divorce decree under Sec. 13(1)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon went on appeal to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh. A Division Bench beard that appeal. By an order dated July 22, 1969 the Division Bench allowed the appeal, set aside the order of the companyrt below and granted a decree for divorce...

facts.text: Appellant filed special leave appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: From this judgment, appellant Swarajya Lakshmi has number companye by special leave on appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Both parties agreed appellant suffered from lepromatous form of leprosy.

anchor.surface_text: Both parties seem to be agreed at Swarajya Lakshmi was suffering from the lepromatous form of leprosy.

facts.text: Respondent contended lepromatous leprosy is incurable and virulent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytends that this was an incurable and virulent form of leprosy while it was companytended on behalf of the appellant...

facts.text: Appellant contended leprosy was curable and she was on way to recovery when petition presented.

anchor.surface_text: ...while it was companytended on behalf of the appellant that the leprosy she was suffering from was curable and. in fact she was on the way to recovery when the petition for dissolution of marriage was presented.

facts.text: Medical evidence on record conflicting and not helpful.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companytesting parties examined doctors in support of their respective companytentions. The doctors agreed that virulent is number really a medical term. Apart from this the medical evidence on record is number very helpful in the sense that they cancel each other.

facts.text: Supreme Court found lepromatous leprosy is virulent and incurable based on medical authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our findings that the form of leprosy from which the appellant suffers was both virulent and incurable, we have companye to the sad but unavoidable companyclusion...

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal and upheld High Court judgment granting divorce.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of these companysiderations we dismiss the appeal and uphold the Judgment of the High Court. In the facts and circumstances of the case we make numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: Lepromatous leprosy recognized by medical authorities as malignant, contagious, and not fully curable.

anchor.surface_text: That lepromatous leprosy is malignant and companytagious seems to be recognised by almost all medical authorities. We append below some of the observations of the medical authorities...

facts.text: Sulphone treatment advances known at time of Hindu Marriage Act 1955 enactment.

anchor.surface_text: Besides it is to be remembered that sulphone drugs were discovered about 1941 and they were very well-known all over the world at the time when the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 was passed.

facts.text: Appellant expecting child in May 1964.

anchor.surface_text: ...but the appellant was taken away by her father to New Delhi in May 1964 as she was then expecting a child,...

anchor.surface_text: Both parties agree that virulent in this companytext is number a medical term. Indeed, the medical evidence on record also makes the same assertion. Virulent therefore according to the dictionary meaning stands for malignant and infectious.

anchor.surface_text: In order, however, to be entitled to a decree of divorce a party has to prove that his spouse has been suffering from a form of leprosy which is number only virulent but also incurable and further that the spouse companycerned has been suffering from this ailment for a period of at least three years before the presentation of the petition. Clearly, enough, the companyditions under which divorce is to be allowed are far more stringent than the companyditions under which judicial separation may be granted.

issues.text: Was the leprosy of Swarajya Lakshmi of an incurable and virulent form?

anchor.surface_text: The main companytroversy between the parties before us turned round the question Was the prosy of Swarajya Lakshmi of an incurable and virulent form ? Both parties seem to be agreed at Swarajya Lakshmi was suffering from the lepromatous form of leprosy.

issues.text: What is the meaning of the word 'virulent' in the context of Section 13(1)(iv) of the Hindu Marriage Act?

anchor.surface_text: Both parties agree that virulent in this companytext is number a medical term. Indeed, the medical evidence on record also makes the same assertion. What, then, is the meaning of the word virulent?

issues.text: Whether lepromatous leprosy is an incurable form of leprosy for the purposes of Section 13(1)(iv)?

anchor.surface_text: We shall number deal with the next and also the more important question as to whether lepromatous leprosy is incredible. The medical witnesses in this case have given their views on this subject.

issues.text: Whether the stricter conditions for divorce under Section 13(1)(iv) compared to judicial separation under Section 10(1) require proof of both virulence and incurability for at least three years?

holdings.text: Virulent in the context of Section 13(1)(iv) of the Hindu Marriage Act means malignant and infectious, according to dictionary meaning.

anchor.surface_text: Virulent therefore according to the dictionary meaning stands for malignant and infectious. We shall now proceed to consider whether lepromatous leprosy which is the type from which the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not a medical term; rejected Hindu law precedents as unreliable guide; relied on dictionary definitions from Chambers, Webster, Oxford.

holdings.text: Lepromatous leprosy is a virulent form as it is malignant and contagious, recognised by medical authorities.

anchor.surface_text: That lepromatous leprosy is malignant and contagious seems to be recognised by almost all medical authorities. We append below some of the observations of the medical authorities

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning applied; quotes from medical texts like Behl, Cochrane, Manson confirming malignant, contagious nature.

holdings.text: Lepromatous leprosy is an incurable form of leprosy for purposes of Section 13(1)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter in our opinion the disease from which the appellant suffers can be described as an incurable form of leprosy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical evidence conflicting and unhelpful; relied on authorities like Manson, Price, Sutton, Cochrane showing requires lifelong sulphone therapy, relapses possible; legislature aware of sulphones since 1941 when enacting 1955 Act.

holdings.text: The appellant suffered from virulent and incurable leprosy for not less than three years preceding the petition.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our findings that the form of leprosy from which the appellant suffers was both virulent and incurable, we have come to the sad but unavoidable conclusion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted lower court finding on facts; applied S.13(1)(iv) requirements confirmed by medical authorities.

holdings.text: The case satisfies Section 13(1)(iv) for divorce decree; appeal dismissed, High Court judgment upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of these considerations we dismiss the appeal and uphold the Judgment of the High Court. In the facts and circumstances of the case we make no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Virulent and incurable lepromatous leprosy for requisite period established; permission under S.14(1) previously granted.

holdings.text: Conditions for divorce under S.13(1)(iv) more stringent than judicial separation under S.10(1): requires virulent + incurable for 3 years vs. virulent for 1 year.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly, enough, the conditions under which divorce is to be allowed are far more stringent than the conditions under which judicial separation may be granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory comparison shows legislative intent for stricter proof for divorce.

holdings.text: Conduct of parents in arranging marriage irrelevant to statutory grounds for divorce.

anchor.surface_text: While we have ourselves considerable suspicions in our mind that this perhaps true, we have taken great care not to allow this fact to have any weight in the matter of deciding this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Focus on welfare of spouses and children, not parental sins; marriage sacrament but statute governs divorce.

holdings.text: Humane social approach to leprosy does not override statutory right to divorce.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt that this is absolutely correct about what should be the social approach to leprosy but to our mind this should not provide any justification for compelling a husband to live

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature considered consequences when providing relief; law-makers do not treat divorce lightly.
